title: Rising Rents, Wary Buyers Means Now Might Be the Time to Buy an Investment Property
text:
Uncertainty is plaguing real estate markets around the world, with political and economic worries keeping potential buyers from committing to new homes.



As a consequence, opportunistic investors may consider getting into the landlord game themselves, snapping up properties to rent out. An added incentive is that in some regions, there has seen an uptick in luxury rentals as buyers stay on the sidelines and sellers opt to hold out for a better market.



In New York, for example, consumers may be looking to wait out the market for a lower price or, alternatively, keep their assets to invest elsewhere. And they have more options for luxury rentals, as developers of those buildings are creating the same amenities that people have come to expect in luxury condominiums.



Some areas of London have seen double-digit rent inflation, and with sales prices so low, investors are set to take advantage, according to a report Thursday by Home.co.uk, an online property portal. Neighborhoods, like Haringey, have already seen prices grow, and the real estate website predicts median sales prices will start to stabilize as a result.



More: For a Safer Bet in a Tough Luxury Market, Consider the Penthouse

Investors often look to cities with high rates of tourism for deals, so Miami is also seeing increased interest, said Stephanie Anton, president of Luxury Portfolio International. And she noted that consumers in smaller southern towns, such as Charleston, North Carolina, and Austin, Texas, are also picking up properties with intentions of short- or long-term rentals.



Although some may be tempted to wait for further cuts, prices are low enough for buyers to take the plunge, agents said. And, for potential buyers who plan to rent their properties out, getting in now means they can take advantage of high rents.

More: Amid Political Changes, Buyers Would Be Wise to Consider Prime Central London﻿



New York



In New York, rents are up across the board, with luxury units up almost 4% in August since this time last year, according to a Douglas Elliman report released earlier this week. The median rental price for luxury apartments, defined by Elliman as the top 10% of leases, was $8,000 a month in August, up 3.9% compared to $7,700 the previous year.



Demand is high for apartments, partially because people are renting instead of buying, said Hal Gavzie, executive manager of leasing for Douglas Elliman. Worries about a potential recession and other uncertainties have sidelined some buyers, while others may be waiting for falling sales prices in the luxury sector to hit rock bottom.



And prices are still slipping. The median sales prices dropped 6.2% to $6.15 million in the second quarter of 2019, compared to $6.56 million for the same time period in 2018, another Elliman report found.

More: Forget Perfectly Timing the Market and Focus on What You Can Do Instead﻿



So, for sellers who don’t need to cash in right away, renting out their property now might mean getting a better price in the future.



“Because the market is not a seller’s market, if the seller is in a position where they don’t need the income right away, it might make sense to wait,” said Vickey Barron, an agent with Compass in Manhattan.



And she has plenty of clients ready to rent out these same luxury properties.



“In the luxury market, people are looking for quality and a certain lifestyle,” Ms. Barron explained. “It’s more about finding that than the price.”

More: When Renovating to Sell, Focus on Kitchen Modernization, But Don’t Go Overboard﻿



Although New York City has always had a healthy supply of rentals, developers have found an enthusiastic audience for luxury buildings with top-of-the-line amenities.



“There’s an increasing interest in rentals that offer the luxury and lifestyle you’d find in an upscale condo,” said Richard Cantor, a principal at the real estate agency Cantor Pecorella.



The firm is handling sales at the Alyn, a 20-story rental tower on the Upper East Side slated for completion at the end of the year. It boasts a fitness center created by Homage, a fitness design company, four levels of parking and a playroom designed by the children’s architecture firm Silver Hill Atelier. Rents there are between $10,000 and $35,000 a month, and the project is already over 80% leased, Mr. Cantor said.



His clients range from empty nesters to new New Yorkers still getting a feel for the city. Others want to invest their assets in the stock market, where they may get better returns, he added.

From Penta: Future Returns: Investing in the ‘Food Revolution’﻿



Cantor Pecorella also handles sales, and is currently representing Celeste Gramercy, a mid-market project. There, Mr. Cantor is seeing some investors purchasing homes they intend to rent, as well as parents buying homes for their children.



Ms. Barron said it’s an “excellent time to buy,” noting low interest rates and good deals in the city.



“People always think they can get a better deal, but they can wait too long and miss the curve,” she said.

More: A Fed Rate Cut Could Be Good News for Some Luxury Housing Market Sectors

London

Concerns over Brexit have shaken consumer confidence in London, and sales in the city have been in a tailspin as uncertainty continues. But as prices have plummeted, investors are taking advantage.



Now, a dearth of available rental property and much reduced asking prices has brought investors back into the London market, despite government measures increasing taxes on landlords, the Home.co.uk report found.



“London takes the spotlight this month as soaring rents tempt investors back into the capital’s letting market,” the report said. “Rock-bottom sales and rental stock levels are initiating a revitalization of the London sales market, led by several key boroughs.”



Inventory is down, and six London boroughs—Wandsworth, Hackney, Haringey, Hammersmith and Fulham, Southwark and Islington—have seen significant rent increases. Competition from buyers for limited product is stabilizing sales prices, the report found.

More: Development Pipeline Is a Weather Vane for Home Prices

“Sales stock levels in the central London boroughs haven’t been this low for several years and prices look set to surge accordingly as demand picks up,” Doug Shephard, director at Home.co.uk, said in the report.



Renewed investor interest is in spite of a 3% increase to the stamp duty tax in 2016 for those who own more than one property, as well as the phasing out of a mortgage interest deduction on buy-to-let properties in 2017. The deduction has been lowered by 25% each year since and will be eliminated in 2020.



Knight Frank’s August Prime London Lettings Index found the number of new prospective tenants increased by 22% year over year compared to July 2018. At the same time, the number of new lettings listings grew by 1%.



“This growing imbalance between supply and demand will continue to exert upward pressure on rental values,” the report said.

More: As the Market Produces ‘New’ Neighborhoods, Who Decides How Much a Name is Worth?

In addition, would-be buyers in London have looked to rent, as uncertainty in the sales market continues. Super-prime leases, those more than £2,000 (US$2,466) a week, signed in the second quarter of 2019 was 40, the highest figure for the second quarter in more than five years, according to the report.



And like prime sellers in New York, many have opted to rent rather than sell until price inflation returns.



Miami and Other Southern U.S. Locales



Rents were up in Miami in August in all sectors, and the average was $1,729 a month in August, an increase of 4% year over year, the real estate website RentCafe reported.



Ms. Anton said Miami is one place investors look for second-homes they intend to rent, largely because its year-round warm weather and proximity to beaches attracts so many visitors.

More: Whisper Listings are Most Effective When a Home is Truly Unique

“It’s happening in markets where we know that there is a tourist population,” she said. “If they want to rent, they can do long-term, but also short-term.”



That’s happening in places like her home city of Austin, as well, Ms. Anton noted. Some buyers may forgo a luxury property for two or more mid-level properties they can easily rent, she added.



“It's a big part of the population, and part of the people who are buying property to rent it out,” she said. “They have a home and they are staying there and then maybe investing in mid-tier properties to rent out.”
